name: Mass Effect
description: As Commander Shepard, you lead an elite squad on a heroic, action-packed adventure throughout the galaxy. Discover the imminent danger from an ancient threat and battle the traitorous Saren and his deadly army to save civilization. The fate of all life depends on your actions!

reviews.review_text: Having sunk over 200 hours into this game alone, over 500 hours in total for this whole trilogy how can I not say this is one of the greatest adventures I've had ever in my life. This is not just a game that you play like call of duty just to pass the time, this series has become a religious experience, a lifestyle.  When I first loaded up this game I had no idea what I was in for, but it gave off a seriously special energy and I got sucked into a living, breathing universe...full of wonder, full of excitement and it shook me like Star Wars KOTOR never could (and is the reason why and how I even bought this game).   Don't even think is this game going to be good enough for my $20 (Australia), if you can afford it just buy it and open your heart, mind and soul to this amazing experience. Don't listen to the haters crying about there ME3 endings that they never got etc, its the journey, the friendships you create, the relationships you forge, the hearts you can break, the tears that can be shed. Don't miss out.  Love you Bioware, you have turned my world and my views, my inner essence, my personality upside down, inside out and blown it to hell and back (in a good way). You've made me mad, you've made me sad, made me happy, made me cry, made me scream the roof down. How many games can you get emotionally, psychologically and spiritually attached to.  Games are artwork like paintings and music for this technological generation, this game is a work of art. AAA+

(Just for clarification I've played this game like 6 times outside of steam)  There are games you like. There are games you love, and replay many times.  And then there are the games which almost bring a tear to your eye every time you start them. The games which you've played enough times, you can quote the dialogue, speedrun the game perfectly, and remember every encounter from. Because those games are masterpieces.  This is one of those games.

Quite simply, this is an essential purchase and gaming experience. Excellent storyline, great characters and voice-acting and a genuinely involving plot. Your gameplay decisions and character looks even port over to Mass Effect 2 once you've finished (and ME2 is an absolute must-play title!) Sale price is less than a pint of cheap beer now. What are you doing reading this? Buy it and get playing!

Mass Effect is one of the greatest games i ever played and one of my favorites. You really need to play Mass Effect 1 before Mass Effect 2, it's the start of an epic franchise, that you dont want to miss. Amazing story, amazing atmosphere and amazing world! I really haven't found anything negative in this game.  I have finished the game 2 times and i will do it many times again, i never get bored of playing it. One of the greatest games and RPG's out there!  A MUST-BUY FOR EVERYONE!
If you've played this and you don't like it, then you're just a big stupid jellyfish.
After 7 years, its still one of the best story telling RPG ever

This is the begining of somthing great, you may pick it up during a sale or because it's cheap, however the second you begin playing, you're drawn in, and from then on you are inside of an amazing universe, just ignore all the ME3 hate and have fun.  (And if the ending is REALLY a big issue to you then remember it's the journey that counts, not the end-game.)
The pinnacle of virtual story telling.

Mass Effect games are always fun to talk about, never sure if I love or hate them more.  The 1st game in the series undoubtedly plays most like an RPG of the 3 games, though even then, it would stand as a rather odd RPG when compared to others.   For those that have played BioWare's best work: Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic, you'll notice some similar sub-stories, characters, and styles. I mention this only because the influence is strongest in the 1st game, when the series hasn't really defined itself completely.  Anyways, it stands as the black sheep of the trilogy for its odd mix of RPG and 3rd person shooter mechanics. It does, however, possess strengths the others lack. The Lovecraftian horror influence is pretty clear in some of the side quests that take you to remote planets -- the fear of the unknown, the ominous music all play into this.   The vehicular sections on the remote planets are a bit clunky, but they do a good job of establishing mystery -- you don't know quite what you're going to find. This works well in both reinforcing the trilogy's whole narrative and the general style the narrative embodies: the unknown, powerful threat, the dirty/dark sci-fi.  Of course, one has to forgive the incessantly repeated interiors and textures for the side quests, this game lacks polish. If one can get past it, one will find a series of stories that help add to and fill in Mass Effect's universe, even setting things up for the sequels well.  If one does everything, the game will take roughly 45-50 hours. If one moves through the narrative alone, you can complete it in 10-15 hours.   The main story narrative has the strongest KOTOR infuence. KOTOR was a campaign across a series of planets, not an entire galaxy. Mass Effect too, is composed of fairly long missions on a small handful of planets -- each a sort of individual story that connects to the larger narrative. Or there's the fact that in both KOTOR and ME1, the player follows the antagonist, or rather retraces their steps, to discover their motivations and goals, across different planets.   This is contrasted, then, with Mass Effect 2 and 3, where the meat of the games is composed of much more compact and exposition heavy missions with a lot of tight, polished shooting across many locations.  The shooting mechanics seem to, in principle, be based on what many call a Gears of War or GTAIV cover based system. Player pops in and out of cover. However, it's pretty clunky, the player doesn't stick too well to cover and cannot navigate it very well.   Add in the fact that weapons, armor, and upgrades are doled out in a traditional RPG manner, with damage stats being compared, unique drops, the skill point based system of character leveling. and a huge inventory to sort through, and one will begin to notice that things seem out of place.   It is not so much that these elements are bad in and of themselves, but more that they don't belong together. As if the developers were unsure of what kind of game they wanted Mass Effect to be.  After several replays, I've come to realize that they don't do a very good job of leading up to what is supposed to be the central twist of the narrative, the big reveal about the focus of the whole trilogy, the thing to make the games all connect. Avoiding spoilers, I mean the event with the 'virtual intelligence' on Virmire late in the game.   Anyone replaying will notice that the game will go so far as to basically tell, through other characters, the player directly what the narrative reveals later in a manner obviously meant to be climactic. It is again, odd, unpolished, and atypical of BioWare, much like the entirety of the game.  **SPOILERS AHEAD**  Besides feeling out of place and sometimes unpolished, the game has a lot of content, has mechanics that work even if feeling awkward, and manages to present an engaging narrative -- I still get rather excited when Joker commands the fleet upon Sovereign in one of the final scenes. Mass Effect's cinematic presentation is fantastic and never fails to make me feel invested in the story.   (If, again, one can forgive some of the cliches like checking the body of the villain to make sure he's dead only to discover him alive or thinking the hero is dead only to have him reemerge triumphantly. I think it is possible to view these little storytelling sins sympathetically, cute little mistakes of young Mass Effect)  I spent around 150 hours (100 on my Steam copy) on this game over several playthroughs. As I said at the beginning, I have a lot of issues with the series and it definitely isn't perfect. I can't deny though, that they do some things so well, and are so unique that they are games we can conclude are worth playing, worth discussing, worth evaluating.  Despite the game's flaws, odd qualities, and weird inability to define itself, I have to recommend it for all it does well, for starting a great trilogy and for leading into the best game of the series: Mass Effect 2.
I've played it to completion 4 times and loved each time.

One of my new personal favorite series.  I played the Mass Effect triology not expecting too much. This game takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions. You fall in love with the characters around you and really feel like you are fighting for a true cause. I loved this game so much, it's now higher than the Bioshock series (which was my all time favorite). I've never cried so much when a character left or I made the wrong choice. Mass Effect 3's ending absolutely destroyed me. I completed it only a day ago and I still feel really depressed over it. In general though, this game is an extraordinary masterpiece. The character development, the choices, the gameplay and the story are just so amazing. I loved every minute of this game franchise and I recommend this to everyone. I really felt like I was Commander Shepard. I felt like I was making a difference. I felt like I was saving the world. I really felt like everything I did, everywhere I went, that people, no the WORLD was depending on me and the choices I made. I've never felt so much for a video game in a long time. 10/10 Broke my heart, made me fall in love and made me happy when I made the right choices.  Thank you Bioware. Another absolutely amazing series from you. 'I'll always love you Garrus'

One of my favorite games ever! I love it and I never get bored to it. It does not matter how much time passes, I always keep coming to play this masterpiece! The rich story and the unique characters truly makes you feel amazed.  It is very hard for me to find any other game which could compete...yet.

Maybe the best sci-fi RPG (up there with KoTOR) and one of the best story-based computer games. The main story, written by Karpyshyn et al, shines accompanied by a wealth of developed support characters with their own backgrounds and stories.   Pros: + amazing main story + choices DO MATTER at personal and global level + a very large number of support characters each with corresponding stories + variety in weapons, characteristics, skills etc + optimal duration, not too short but also it does not drag forever + music and sound effects + some really awesome moments especially near the end  Cons: - graphics show their age  - environments of side missions are repeated (especially the bases), making some quests rather boring - some occasional crashes    All-in-all: A must-have game!

This game really did it for me. While not flawless the gameplay experience it gave me was among the best I have yet to encounter in my gaming 'career'. Apart from my first playthrough of Final Fantasy 7 and, of course, Mass Effect 2 nothing comes to my mind that holds up in comparison.  The premise does not seem that extraordinary at first glance. You play as Commander Shepard (either male or female, your choice) and basically you are going to prevent the annihilation of every major civilisation in the galaxy. Pretty standard so far. But the world building in this game is so complex, so detailled it blew me away. Every now and then you get entries in your Codex where you can read about the many spacefaring races, some important historic events or the different technologies you are utilizing in the game. I loved how they put that much effort into something many gamers won't even bother to read because it is not important at all if you just want to progress the story.  What really makes the game come to life is its host of memorable characters. There are innumerable people you encounter, many of which can be spoken with, often offering multiple dialogue-tree options. Some of those will join your team and become your companions. Since I engaged all of my companions in conversations regularly between missions I started to really care about them. They are fully fleshed out personalities, each with his own motivations and wishes. The main villains, the Reapers, are mostly only hinted at. But you never forget them and their looming presence in the background gives the story a dire urgency. The Reapers' henchmen you are battling are nothing grand but they serve their purpose well.  The gameplay combines elements of roleplaying, shooter and exploration games and the result gave me great joy. There were some rather unpleasant moments while traversing the surface of the more mountainous planets but thankfully there weren't that many of them. The majority of the game is spent either engaging NPCs in conversations or shooting at enemies. Both aspects are done very well, although the shooter portion got a tiny bit repetitive at the end. But since I did every available sidequest and played almost nonstop for several days until I was done that might be my own fault.  The skillsystem is solid and you get tons of loot to equip your characters with.  There are several occasions when you have to make a decision that will have repercussions in the later games. Some are more personal and affect if a specific character will survive to come back in the sequels. Some have a galactic impact. In one case you decide between exterminating an entire race or giving them another chance. All of these moments came back to me vividly while playing Mass Effect 2 and being confronted with the consequences of my own actions.
Anderson with the right hook to udina's jaw, 10/10 would get grounded at citadel again

What if I told you there was a science-fiction roleplaying game where you lead a vastly diverse crew to stop the Council's golden agent after he goes rogue?  Now, what if I told you that in said game, you make choices that can drastically effect multiple boss fights and just how diverse your crew is?  Now stay with me, what if I told you in said game, your dialogue tree has VOICED dialogue provided by Mark Meer (if you are playing male) or the lovely Jennifer Hale (if you are playing female, obviously.)  Okay, okay, sound interesting? Now how about this... What if I told you that this is Part 1 to a fully thought out and innovative trilogy where you can import not only your saves, but your very character (from your choices to your appearance) from the first game?  What if I told you this game also has low enough specs to be played on most laptops? Seriously, if you're a RPG fan and you haven't played this yet because the controversy of the third game's ending has discouraged you: play this trilogy anyways. This is a lore-filled game with a fully narrated codex. A fully narrated codex!!! You can spend hours just listening to the codex alone!  Seriously, the entire trilogy will provide you hundreds of hours of immersion in a well crafted universe.  Just buy this if you like roleplaying games of any sort.

My favorite video game series ever.   While ME1 is somewhat outdated (in gameplay terms), it's playable. If you want to get into the ME series, don't commit the same mistake I almost did - START WITH ME1 since skipping to Me2 ruins a significant part of the experience.

I can't believe I've never played this game before now. I'm totally sucked into this game, even if its just roaming around the universe looking for side quests or that last metal deposit. If you like third-person shooters with RPG elements, side quests, space, choose-your-dialogue games, flirting with aliens, and games with fleshed out lore for its world, Mass Effect is for you. I like that I can develop my Shepard the way I like and pick my teammates and how to interact with them outside of missions. I haven't played ME2 or ME3 yet, but I definitely plan to!

This game is the start of an epic trilogy that is rich with story and interactivity. Developed by the same company that made the popular Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, this game improves upon the role-playing system presented in that game. This third-person shooter is worthy of being one of BioWare's crowning achievements. People that desire hours of entertainment should definitely check this one out.

After playing Dragon Age for a bit some years ago (I don't know why I quit? I had better things to do I guess) I decided to try out another infamous title from Bioware: Mass Effect. I had no idea what to expect and just went in blank. I entered a world full of Turians, Salarians, and a lot of other races I was quite sure I would never remember.   But as the game progressed, I became quite fond of Turians. I met my first Volus along the way. I learned what a Specter was and what was expected of me when I became one. And the conversations. I love the conversations. Instead of watching a scene and waiting until you can play again, you decide how this conversation will end! Will your persuade your teammate to cooperate or will they leave you when you decide to yell at them? It's your decision.  This is a game I'll never forget, and I'll make sure to give Dragon Age another go!

Not much playtime yet on steam but I've played quite a lot on PS3 (90 hours or so) and the steam version is like that but with better graphics, fps, and loading times.  It's a great sci-fi game and it's filled with a lot of exploration, backstory, and lore. The rpg elements are ok-ish and the combat's not polished compared to newer games, but the shooting is serviceable, not absolutely horrible. Just not up to today's standards I'd say.  It's more star trek than any star trek game, because you get to be captain of a ship, make decisions that impact storylines and your relationship with your crew, pursue romantic interests, and explore plenty of planets (though admittedly they are sometimes kinda empty and the buildings are reused very often). And if you really like lore and backstories in your games, this game has plenty and a lot of them are fully voiced. What mass effect really does well is immersing you into its world.  Would definitely recommend this game to anyone even remotely interested in sci fi.

After seeing snippets of Mass Effect 2, I knew I had to play from the beginning. This game is a great start to this three part space opera. The story is deceptively simple. You are Commander Shephard and you must save the galaxy. As you complete the simple story you will have to make decisions that will flesh out the story and in some ways decide on who lives and who dies. Apart from the main story, there are numerous side missions that help develop relationships with fellow characters or influence what happens in the sequels. There is tons of replay value due to the fact that there are different ways to handle various situations in the game. The graphics have aged well, I think. The characters are all memorable. You won't like these characters, you will LOVE them. The relationships you build (or tear down) will follow you in the games to come. Now for the negatives, and I had to squint to see them. I personally found the exploration tedious. The planets you go to are all very detailed, with descriptions about their resources and history, but driving the vehicle to go through some of the rough terrain got to be annoying at times. Thats really the only negative I could think of. A great game that should be tried by everybody.
The video game that started it all. The creation of Mass Effect right here! The creation of Commander Shepard. The creation of the greatest video game trilogy ever! 10/10

Mass Effect is expressed more freely than ever and offers an exciting adventure, set in a beautifully coherent universe. Some defects are still in the game, such as this IA disappointing and a lifetime a bit limited. However, nothing to prevent Mass Effect claim the title of enchanting game or one of the best RPG games, able to delight fans of space operas classy and intelligent. Mass Effect is their greatest achievement thus far. Once again, thank you to Bioware for such generosity.  18/20
emotional wreckage has begun.

Belated review. If you are a sucker for any of the following: spaceships, aliens, storytelling, RPGs, shooters, or sci-fi in general, and haven't yet played Mass Effect... well, what are you waiting for?!? Even though it's a few years old now and has a few minor problems, Mass Effect is still well-worth playing, especially if you have any interest at all in the upcoming ME3. I thought overall it was a really fun game, especially the story aspects. The shooting mechanics are also perfectly fine. The only major gripe I had was the weapon/inventory system. Throughout your journey, you are constantly finding tons of weapons and upgrades, 99% of which are duplicates or unneccessary. The interface for managing weapons is also confusing and cumbersome. But that one thing aside, I pretty much loved everything else about ME1. If you haven't played it yet, get it now!
The best ME game in the trilogy. The characters, thematic elements, and story arc are among the strongest in any RPG I've played.
Cannot romance Rachni Queen.  0/10

Even if I give the game a thumbs up, this one is not for me. There are a few things that really put me off from playing through this game. The combat system is horrible. Fallout 3 struggled to not become a FPS and somehow it worked for the most part, but in this game it just doesn't work either way. It's not a FPS and not an action RPG either. The loot system has been 'simplified' to a point where you keep getting the same items over and over again. You can modify weapons and ammo though.  The story is okay, but it didn't really catch me. Maybe the quite obvious build up for the main character to become the saviour of the universe was a bit too much. The voice acting for the main character does its part by simply being not good.  You can travel to other systems than the ones covered by the main story, but they are boring and at best filled with some generic structures without any deeper meaning. You explore those planets using a vehicle that has one of the worst controls and physics I've ever encountered in a computer game.  The visuals are good for a game from 2008, but the music doesn't really work for the title. It's very bland electronic music that would rather fit in an elevator.  I won't finish the game even if I invested over 16 hours into it so far as I don't see it becoming really interesting and the overall gameplay is just not satisfying. Why I still give it a thumbs up? I still think it's worth a try even if I personally don't like it.

I remember when bioware made great games...this is one of them. If you were looking for an in depth review, all i'll say is this. You wont have a social life anymore...seriously. (also clocked more hours on the 360 version...all 364.3 of them).
Everyone’s favourite Sci-Fi RPG, Still very playable despite its age!

Captain Kirk simulator 2008. A nearly perfect game.   Runs perfect and looks great on Ultra on the crappest of modern craptops. Pro tip, if you encounter the black character textures bug, enter 'viewmode unlit' on the console.

Do you like Deep story RPG's? Do you like choosing your own path? Do you like space and space ships and futuristic weapons?  Do you like plot twists and deep emotional choices and character development?  Bro its like watching a top notch science fiction movie .. but you actually play and direct it yourself.. Amazing game.

Game: Mass Effect 1 Genre: RPG/FPS Developer: Bioware/EA System: Steam (PC) Total Score: 93/100 Value Score: 9.3/10  • Story: 10/10 • Characters: 9/10 • GamePlay: 9/10  • Graphics: 8/10 • Sound: 10/10 • Music: 8/10 • Length: 9/10 • Replay Value: 10/10 • Player Value: 10/10   Pros  +Great Dynamic story that keeps changing depending on what role, what decisions and actions you make in the game.  +Multiple Scenarios, Paths and Endings which leads to multiple playthroughs and thus replay value +Class based gameplay system which allows you to have a different experience each time you play as a different class. +Character customization lets you create your own character in their own appearance, etc +A great mixture of RPG and FPS elements packaged into one game +Fantastic voice acting and a lot of voice over scenes +A great morality system that also plays in what bonuses you would get (i.e. discounts, certain decision options) +Leveling system has quite a depth that ranges from learning unique class abilities to weapon mastery +Save files are interchangeable between Steam and Origin.   Cons  -Some minor glitches could occur such as falling into the floor or certain scenes not being playable from time to time but nothing game breaking and does not happen often or repeatedly -Some of the visual designs look a bit outdated and last gen style (PS2/GCN/Xbox era) -Some of the side missions lead you to similar to same looking areas and structures -Some of the planets are so barren and empty with nothing but fetch quests or extra grinding for weapons and money. -Pinnacle Station DLC is not available for standalone purchases of Mass Effect 1. Only available for Trilogy purchasers. -Bring Down the Sky DLC has to be downloaded separately and installed unlike the description in the store page where it says its available already.
absolutely love this series . best game series iv ever played and it all starts with ME1
run around and shoot geth
story, action, gameplay 10 out of 10 imo
Good stuff!

The whole series is my favorite!!! I always recommend to play the first one because if you start on the 2nd or 3rd...you won't wanna come back to this one because of the quality. They did some major improvements to this series and the story is beautiful! Cannot wait for ME4!!! I will say one thing for the first Mass Effect thats annoying is the glitch in the snow biome quest when all the characters and enemies become pixilated black so its hard to try to kill them but I managed to get through it twice and it goes away once youre out of that mission. They never fixed that glitch though. -sigh- Oh well, still a great game!!! ^-^

I actually spent 20 hours in this game in the last 4 days in Steam offline mode, so ignore Steam playtime.  Mass Effect was a pleasant surprise for me, because of two reasons: I'm not a fan of space opera and sci-fi, and I couldn't get into one of Bioware's well known title - Dragon Age: Origins. But screw them, let's talk about Mass Effect. The game has messy inventory system, clunky animations, pretty straightforward weapon upgrades and doesn't allow progressing after finishing the main story, aaaaaaand... that's it, that's all my criticism for ME. What can I say more about it? Mass Effect is a well-crafted game from head to toe, with nearly all aspects perfected.  First, I freaking love the narrative. In the first 30 minutes, I thought it was some typical pretentious sci-fi piece of ♥♥♥♥ that overcomplicates everything, but nope, the story really hooked me in, even it was just a standard good-vs-evil story filled with cliches. I can't tell exactly what I love about ME's story, but it gave me a sense of real progression, and pushed me forward through each events in the game. Sometime intense, sometime emotional and sometime even silly (especially in romance subplots), and of course it doesn't lack 'epicness' for a sci-fi saga.  Next, the dialogues. There's no such thing as illusive choices. In ME, every choice matters, and not all decisions lead to a good end.    I still feel bad because I accidentally shot Wrax on Virmire, had to replay that section  . Tip: Spend your points in Charisma or Intimidate, they're very important, don't ignore them.  Teammates. Uhuh, this is not your standard companions, your squad mates are TRUE human (or alien) beings with their own unique personality. You know what? I found it more interesting to wandering around the Normandy, talking to my squad mates, rather than exploring the galaxy. And I've never, ever, felt so much difficult in deciding between 2 squad mates' fates. There was no game that made me care so much about my team mates like Mass Effect. Why? Because ♥♥♥♥ you Bioware, you created some of the most memorable and well-developed side characters in any game I've ever played. If I don't see Garrus, Wrex, Liara or Tali in the sequels, many tables will be flipped.  Gunplay hasn't aged well, but it's certainly enjoyable. Tons of weapons, upgrades and special biotic abilities. You don't need to be a strategist to play the game, but it certainly helps if you can order your squad mates to assist you on the battlefield.  Aargh. why, why did I spend the last 7 years without giving a damn about Mass Effect? Why didn't I know about it sooner? Why did I pass on this masterpiece? And why does Garrus's face look low-textured? Anyway, Mass Effect, 10 ♥♥♥♥ing out of 10, heavily recommended. If you are a fan of RPG or sci-fi, play it already. If you don't give a crap about RPG or sci-fi, then still give it a try, because you might like it as much as I do.
A nice game with a chooseable story and a big world. There are a lot of different planets and you can spot many, but not all! I love it! 9/10

The start of what became an epic story. Compared to the next two games in the series, the combat here can feel clunky, and the HUD/Menus aren't as refined, neither are the character models (the screenshot of Shepard in the menu holding the weapons says it all), but the story, the voice acting and the characters themselves are so well done that you almost forget about the rest. The fact that choices you make in this game have an effect on what you experience not only in Mass Effect 2, but 3 as well is amazing.  Seriously, this is a game that I recommend to every sci-fi fan out there because it is simply that good.
Always a fun game to replay. It has a few quirks in the story, but it has an awesome feel and I love the fact that you can customize your male or female protagonist into what you want.
Don't play the other 2 games in the series unless you want this experience ruined  In my book this is the only Mass Effect game and it's great
Awesome game, one of my new favourites. Brilliant for anyone with dreams of roaming the stars with their own ship and crew. The true Captain Kirk experience, just with more robots.

i really reccomend this game to everyone  i reccomend every masseffect game  im glad i grew up with masseffect as a part of my childhood and adult hood the graphics and story and options of what you can do is amazing and so is the designs of buildings weapons and worlds and every place you can travel and go the weapons are handy there are side missions to and tasks to addvance . characters are also amazing with detail but the other nice thing about masseffect games are when you talk to somone you have multi options for what you want to say and do and sometimes if you say the wrong words it can result in good or bad responces but all in all i definitly reccomend this game to everyone 10/10 ((((((i just really reccomend every masseffect game)))))))

I spent hundreds of hrs on this game on the Xbox 360 version and played the 2nd one for over 50hrs (Got it on origin) and the 3rd one for over 150hrs (Origin and Xbox 360) and I can say, this is one of the best game series EVER, great dialogue options, great characters, great gameplay and is great overall... In my opinion the characters are made so well that sometimes they even feel real, and when you end the game you feel empty. I totally recommend you to buy this games! Not to talk about the storyline, it's simply AWESOME... I really don't know what to say about this game, there is too many stuff too say, and each one of them is made Really WELL and it's awesome!!

I may now be hooked on Bioware because of this game. However, I have betrayed all the asari ever by picking the straight romance on my first playthrough. I am so sorry. Darn you Kaidan for being so cute and your name being so close to Kaladin. Also Liara sounds like a 17 year old girl so I felt a little creepy, but I will get over it for the sake of being not-straight.  No but this is a fun shooter+rpg... thing. With a shootload of story. Even if you're one of those people who can't pick mean dialogue options bc you might hurt someone's feelings. It's okay. You can be so Paragon you glow blue. That's a thing.

I'm a little late to the Mass Effect party, but this game deserves its spot among the classics. For anyone who enjoys story-rich games set in a universe jam-packed with lore, this is the game for you! Plus the big fights are really fun, and some of the combat issues they had in ME1 get resolved in the sequels. Great game!

Summary: A great sci-fi RPG with fun dialogue and action. It's a bit rough around the edges, but does not disappoint despite its age.  +It's an epic space adventure, in which you save the galaxy! +Did the above sound awfully generic? Well, I was surprised at the effort they put into creating a whole new universe with numerous alien races and technologies. They even put this optional but very cool information in a codex whenever you interact with objects or people. +A diverse cast of crew members with cool backstories, They even talk to each other when you ride the elevator (and thank gods for that)! +Combat is generally fun. Mostly with guns, as well as whatever technological or biotic (mass manipulating) skills you decide to learn. You can also pause at any time to give orders to your party members. +The 'morality' tree isn't clear-cut good/evil, but renegade/paragon. So your lawful actions don't cancel out your chaotic ones, or vice versa. Instead each contributes to their own separate bar, which enables more dialogue options in the future should you invest the skill points. +For the most part, you're free to do missions (both the main story and side missions) in any order you choose, flying around on your awesome spaceship  -The character movement can be clumsy. I've gotten killed more than once when Shepard decides he can 'take cover' behind a tiny piece of debris. -Vehicular controls are extremely clumsy. ♥♥♥♥ driving on hilly terrain, especially. -Side missions can be pretty repetitive after a while, especially since ~70% of them involve driving around planets that are reskinned versions of each other to get to buildings whose layouts are also copies of each other. -Inventory size limit is not a huge problem, but still a hassle. Why did they bother? -What the other reviewers said about elevators is true. There's too many of them and take too freakin' long!

In depth story, great character choices for gear/weaponry, index with voiced over history of whatever you find in the game, etc. I've played this game over multiple times and I hihgly suggest having it part of your collection. It's one of those games that you'll go back to and can't put down.

The story also follows the Bioware plotline formula of 'visit these four different places in any order, then this last place, then you win' which is getting rather tired at this point.  That being said, it's a memorable game, and I'll probably have sunk about 100+ hours into it before I'm truly done, thanks to it's replayability. Definately worth it at the price steam is selling it for.

Pros: -Story. This isn't surprising. Bioware games tend to be very plot-heavy and less centered on action. More talky-talky bits and extreme decision making. Less shooty-killy. The downside is that while you get a good chunk of the story in the beginning, it doesn't really pick up fully until over halfway through the game. Don't get me wrong. When it picks up, it really picks you up and throws you over the table and repeatedly screws you.  -Decisions. Like in Dragon Age, the choices you make do effect the rest of the gameplay and subsequent events. Impacting in the next two games for the trilogy, though I've yet to play 'em.  -Action. My first rpg shooter. I like that it wasn't so centered on kill-kill-kill. It allowed me time to get into it, and I'm not big on shooters. This doesn't feel like it's utterly in my face. It's third-person shooter, so I think that helps.  -Controls. Very easy to get used to.  -Gameplay. Very few timed events.    Cons:  -Controls. Yes, this is a pro, but in a few cases, it's a con. And it's only a con when you're in a vehicle called the Mako. Mass Effect was a game designed for the console, not the PC. And it shows. Holy hell, does it show. My driving is akin to a drunkard on speed. I managed to flip the damn car over when gravity was on MY side. Every death I suffered was due to that damn car. And you need to use that car a lot. It kills a lot of the fun within the game. Thankfully, it's not essential to the overall game, and if you're not a completionist, you won't have to use it that often.  -The 'lockpicking'. It took me forever to figure out wtf I was supposed to do. The game offers you no direction on that. And in decrypting something, the codes are a bit iffy as opposed to how it is for the xbox or PS3. It's a pain in the ♥♥♥. Once you learn what the hell to do, it's pretty simple. But until you figure it out, it's just banging your head against the wall.  -Characters need more by way of development. What was there was definitely touching, and I'm in NO way saying that these characters aren't awesome in their own right. I was touched by a few of their stories. But perhaps I'm spoiled by DA, and Bioware is pretty known for their character development, interactions, etc.   -Romances. One male romance for a female main character. One female romance for a male main character. And one female romance for either gender main character.  Though I'll give it points for having the bisexual love interest be an alien.   Awesome points:  -The aliens. Lots of variations, and I really like 'em all. Humans are pretty much on the lower rung here. There are prejudices, other alien races don't much care for humans and humans are the minorities. There's a small group of humans that are all Human Pride sort of thing, but they're largely irrelevant.  -The Reapers. I don't want to give any spoilers here, but these are seriously such a badass group of villains. The game made them genuinely scary.  -The planets. This probably won't mean much to those who don't care about lore or anything like that, but I found the short summarizations on the different planets to be pretty damn cool and innovative.    The Ugly:  -The profiles. You cannot make a pretty male Shepherd or a pretty female Shepherd. The textures, lights, shadows, angles will make even the most meticulously done Shepherd fugly. It's highly annoying.  -This is one of those games in which it's hard to figure out the first time you play it. Not controls-wise, but everything else-wise. Where to go, what to see, etc. Largely because this world is so big. It's a solar system and it FEELS like a solar system. However, once you've completed one playthrough, you won't really need a guide anymore. It helps that it's a pretty short game. It could probably be played through in the course of a weekend.

First game in the series and pretty unmatched in terms of story. Very captivating lore and character development, interaction with characters is really indepth and intriguing. Combat is fun, probably a bit clunky by todays standards, but I still greatly enjoy it. One of my top 5 games of all time.

For any gamer out there, Mass Effect is a must play. This game is a third-person, role playing, story-driven shooter and it successfully accomplishes all it sets out to be. The main storyline clocks in at around 13 hours but the game is packed with other missions and planets to explore on your own time. Throughout the exploration and firefights, you will surely become attached to certain characters, so decisions you'll have to make later will put you in a cold sweat. Shooting mechanics in this game are solid, but sometimes feel lacking. As for the leveling system, not all the skill points you earn feel as if they've gone to any use since there is such a large array of skills and plenty of point slots necessary to fill so as to reach the next power. All in all, this game is highly recommended to anyone looking for a fantastic single player game.

What can I say about Mass Effect? It is one of my all-time favorite games. The story is really good and the replay value is high due to the fact that you can create different characters focusing on different abilities. Want to be a soldier with all the toys of destruction or a full biotic with limited weapons, or a technician. You can play a character as these types and some in between.  One of the greatest things about the Mass Effect trilogy is that you can import a completed game character into the next installment of the franchise and get bonuses for completing the last installment and pick your character up where you left off. You of course can always just start a new character as well, but it is the carryover of the character that makes the series really unique.  The only strikes against it is some of the tedium related to exploring planets and inventory wrangling.  Definitely a must buy.

Best ♥♥♥♥-in sci-fi game ever, Best Mass Effect game. Unlike the other two games it actually felt like a sci-fi rather than a coated James Bond movie. Shame that Bioware ended up in EA's bed, because what could have followed this game could have been 10x better than what got produced.  If you're wondering why this game is better? Play it. I'll give you some hints  1. It's actually an RPG - Something Bioware forgot in its sequels is giving the player choices that actually matter, in this you can truly feel like you're choosing your own path rather than having it forced on you  2. The Reapers - At this point, we didn't know much about the reapers, but that's why they were such a great plot point: because they were mysterious. Perhaps it would have been better that way, keeping the player in the dark about them while fighting them. Mass Effect 2 kind of lost the feeling that the Reapers generated and by Mass Effect 3 they pretty much took a back seat the ♥♥♥♥ing Cerberus  3. It gives you a villain to rally around - We all hated Saren, not because he was a bad character but because he was a bad guy, and he did that so well. Harbinger just assumed control of people, we had very little interaction with him.   4. Feels like an actual epic sci fi - What the sequels tried to do and failed is to keep the story epic while making it also feel like a summer thriller... bad move. Mass Effect throws environments at you that are really alien, combined with its freaky techno music that haunts you to the core. Sure, you often get the generic mountain planets, but I think they managed to make it work somewhat, and on that note  5. Exploration - I get it, this isn't the U.S.S. Enterprise, you're hunting a criminal, but that doesn't mean you can't have a look around while you're out and about. You get to read up on strange planets, (the galaxy map usage in this is better too), explore them in a hilariously buggy tank, and do whatever you want. They are empty, for the most part, but it still feels fun. ME2 kind of continued it, but the lack of vehicular exploratation (sans the hammer) really didn't give the same vibe. Don't get me started on resource hunting in ME3  There's a bunch of other stuff I didn't touch on. Is it perfect? Hell no, it definitely has flaws, but I rather would have seen them get fixed instead of axed in the second game. It's really quite sad.  ♥♥♥♥ you EA

Mass Effect was Bioware's attempt to create a new breed of RPGs. The cinematic RPG. In doing so they abandoned much of what is usually associated with a Bioware RPG and replaced it with this attempt at creating a 'movie' feel for the game.  The result is far from that however, the storyline is standard Bioware but the new dialog wheel introduced to tell it is a garbled mess that doesn't always reply the way you want it to and this takes heavily away from the connection you usually feel with the main character of an RPG.  The gameplay and combat seems like a sci-fi Oblivion style but this was not a good combat system to begin with and the extremely small and linear maps of Mass Effect makes progression feel rather dull.  Perhaps my favorite part of Mass Effect, and the only part I feel was up to Bioware's usual quality, was the backstory of the universe the game is set it. Very high quality.  Overall this is a mediocre game to me. A game that tries to deliver an 'experience' but fails.

This game is great, not the best, but it is certainly one of the better games on Steam. It has aged rather well, and while a few aspects of it are very dated and can be annoying, such as the MAKO or hacking minigames, but the rest of the game such as the story, combat and voice acting (save for a few VERY minor cases) has aged rather well. There are a few graphic issues here and there however, but these can be overlooked or fixed within the game via the console.  All in all I'd highly suggest this game! Solid story, great action and a lore-rich universe make for an awesome time.

Meanwhile shooting, it's okay but your kinda op even with the normal guns, heck you could speed run without leaving starting weapons/armor. 4/10  Dialogue/Characters Now this is the main reason I was interested in the games. The dialogue is very interesting and the story is very cool (especially the last battle) and you will stay immersed the entire time, until combat. The characters you find are cool and you will actually get a connection, they put more time into dialogue and characters rather than combat and it payed off, there isn't very much fighting and more talking which is great. What can I say! Hands down the best FPS/RPG ever made. The whole series was breathtaking. The stories were deep and immersive. It was like playing a game and watching a great show. The combat structure was designed very well. It is easy to select weapons and choose your abilities without ever leaving the combat screen. The enemy AI uses cover effectively and uses tactics to manuver and flank when possible. This is not a rush and kill everything in sight game. Use your squad commands and utiilze cover or you will be anihilated. As commander you can take any path you choose in the game. If you want to be a saint or a sinner its up to you. Try as I might I cannot find a flaw in the game series. I've played then for hundreds of hours and I still enjoy them. About the only thing i can complain about is the secondary mission objective list in the third installment does not work well. There is no way to tell if you completed the mission or not and sometime no way to know where you need to go back to to complete it. So take lots of notes. Other than that this is the best series I have ever played and I cry at night knowing there will be no more. I guess 3 is the magic number.

** WARNING ** You must execute this game in compatibility mode if you own Windows Vista, 7 or 8. Use Windows XP Service Pack 2, running as administrator doesn't work. You must directly go in the Steam Mass Effect files under binaries in order to launch the game in compatibility mode. You can easily find Youtube videos if you require more help. Once you've done this once, the game should always start normally after. ALSO, there are only a few resolution options, up to 1280x1024. If you play on a 1920x1080 monitor, it's quite the pain.  With this said, before I write a formal review on this game, I must say this: Mass Effect is an EXCELLENT game, however, if you cannot or do not want to play with these issues, you should not buy this game, or buy it on a console, I know for a fact the Xbox 360 version has no issues at all. If you can play with these issues, you will have a phenomemal time. Both Mass Effect 2 and 3 work perfectly fine, so in my opinion, it is still worth it, even if it's just to be able to import a ME1 save to ME2.

It's been quite a while since an RPG has kept me THIS HOOKED for the duration of the game. Mass Effect is one of the greats when it comes to Action RPGs (or ARPGs, if anyone calles it that).  Pros:  + Fantastic story and writing that truly drags you in and doesn't let go + Wide array of characters, and they are all deep and interesting + Incredible voice acting, with people like Seth Green and Keith Davis having voices + Loads of different ways to play, different builds and squads to pick, and a deep upgrade and weapon system + Massive amounts of replayability + Huge world with tonnes of optional quests + Music fits well with the theme, and is well made + Quite long. I clocked in at around 15 hours, but I didn't do alot of the side quests. With all the optional content, I would say the game is about 25-30 hours long  Cons:  - The game has a little bit too much customizability, if you can understand that. It can literally take minutes to change all the gear and equipment, and it should have been simplified just a little bit to make it snappier and more enjoyable. It's not that it's hard to understand, you just waste a lot of time on it - Dialog options are sometimes not entirely clear on what you character will actually say, in what tone he will say it in, if he's being sarcastic ETC. Can lead to some unintentional speech that can affect your relationships on the Normandy  - Optimization is a little wonky, and you can expect some sudden frame drops here and there  Overall rating: 8.5/10 A must play for RPG fans!

Background: This was my first playthrough and i cleared about 95% of the sidemissions. I have not played any Mass Effect titles before. It got recommended a lot, so I bought it in summersale to finally get my hads on the legendary saga.  Short review: I am not really into heavy roleplaying. Dialogue/Running around/Fighting felt about 50/40/10. Played on veteran (highest possible difficulty on 1st playthrough) and didn't feel challenged by any fight. Game is as old as it is so a lot of gameplay mechanics felt outdated. Story is okay, characters well-written. Beware of elevators and lightning bugs.  For everyone stil reading on: Welcome to the longer abstract on 'Elevator Simulator Effect 1'. (You really spend a long time in elevators in this game so excuse the joke)  Mass Effect is a game that recieved a lot of recommendations so i finally got around to try it out and play it through. I can't say that I would recommend it. The game is quite old and i don't feel that it aged well. Slight shader-bugs where my party turned into black blobs were quite offputting aswell (didn't happen too often fortunately and could be fixed with some console-tempering).  I understand that Mass Effect is mostly a storydriven game and storywise it felt slightly better than average. It didn't really catch me. You can blame that on me not being the type of player who enjoys standing around for 15 minutes and listening to dialogue. I relied heavily on reading subtitles as fast as i can and getting back into action.  Speaking of action: Fights make about 10% or less of the gameplay. The fight system felt clunky, party management outside of 'go there and fire away' wasn't really needed. There were occasions where i got oneshot by me being a dunce and stepping into enemy rockets but aside of that, combat didn't feel challenging or tactical at all. I mostly let my party hack enemies and make them float through the air while shooting them with pistols (heatsink upgrades for unlimited bulletstorm). Maybe Liara and Talia are op, but the last fight was over in about 15-20 seconds without me really doing anything (some bug prevented me from firing my guns there).   I played on veteran and understand that there are higher difficulties available on 2nd playthrough. I don't see the point in that. Why not enable them upfront?  Side Missions feel mostly like chores. Planets and structures on it get repetitive really quickly and pay out well. Stores barely have anything worth to buy so i was walking around with 999 omnigel and 9999999 credits during the two/three final missions.  Main Missions are interesting and Character development is a plus. The dialogues were all around well written.  I think i would have enjoyed the game more if it cut all the walking around, fighting and boring riding-around-in-your-gummyball-vehicle-on-planet-surfaces sequences (i despise this vehicle after using it that much). As it is, the gameplay feels too old and drags down the overall enjoyment of the game too much.  EDIT: corrected some spelling mistakes//2016-07-04

This game is a solid mixture of RPG and action with a captivating story line and exciting combat.   It's maybe a step back from the previous line of D&D games BioWare has published in terms of choices. There are I think 6 classes to choose from, but I have found the vanguard to be defunct. The soldier and tech classes work well, but since you absolutely need the guns, I think the pure biotic class is a bit weak. You can't select an alignment, and you can only choose to be the nice guy or the badass in your speech options. It still gives you some options to go for when talking to people. There are two possible skills to improve that widen your speech possibilities which I found quite crucial. Most of the time it affects rewards only, but sometimes you can unlock additional storylines too.  The combat system is fairly simple. You have a choice of 4 weapons, however most classes are trained in one or two of those, and your combat effectiveness depends on this heavily. You can unlock extra abilities by improving your skills. These are available during combat and some of them are very useful, however some are available under different names but do the same thing. The cover system is a bit clunky but you can learn the way it works after some time.  Overall I have enjoyed this game a lot and I recommend it to sci-fi and rpg fans alike.

This is a really great space opera. The story is intriguing, and the characters deep. The combat however isn't much to brag about, and the inventory system was probably designed during the BioWare New Year's Eve party. But in this game, you have a lot of control over the personality of your character. The later games take a bit away from you, but here you almost always have a choice between being a jerk or a saint (You'll get this reference if you play the game) in every situation.  There are some mundane things though. You control a vehicle for most of the side missions called 'The Mako', and I really do not like this thing. It's definitely not designed for PC controls like the keyboard. And the planets you drive it around on very often have idiotic terrain designs so you will get very frustrated when trying to go anywhere.  Also, the side missions can get very repetetive, with reuse of the same buildings and layouts. The variation of the enemy battle lines aren't much either, you'll hear someone shout 'I will destroy you!' a lot.  However the later games fixes these issues, but you'd still want to play this game if you want the full experience of the storyline. So I still recommend it.

If you consider yourself a gamer, you must play through these games at least once to gain an appreciation for this masterpiece of game design. The first Mass Effect game has some issues, especially in that it has a slow beginning, but the game picks up and keeps going at a high quality right up until the finale of the third game. The item & inventory system is a mess and the whole game is a unfulfilling loot-grind of cleaning up your inventory from all the stuff you get ... mostly worse weapons than you already have, even though sometimes you get one that is insignificantly stronger. The inventory space is limited, so that you will quickly get to a point were you have to delete some stuff. And there we have the greatest weakness of the game, as the interface is clearly designed for consoles - IT TAKES AGES TO CLEAR THE INVENTORY! The Mass Effect series is one of my all-time favorites, followed closely by the Witcher. I have played at least 6 campaigns since I first bought the game several years ago.  Mass Effect is one of the best story- and choice-driven RPG games I've played since Baldur's Gate. It's a space opera with an incredible plot and amazing choice mechanics--your decisions matter in the long term and will determine both the consequences of this game and of Mass Effect 2 and 3--and it has aged very well as a result.  Character development is, in my opinion, second-to-none. The NPCs in your crew--and even some who aren't in your crew--have interesting relationships with Shepard, interesting backstories, and (despite the letdown of the Mass Effect 3 ending) fantastic character arc conclusions, which are even better if you get Mass Effect 3's Citadel DLC. The game universe is enormous and complex, and the story really gives you a good sense of how large it is as you fight your way through planets to complete missions.   There are three downsides:   1) The combat mechanics are rather boring. It's a third-person shooter that uses cover mechanics and not much else. You don't have ammo problems--your weapons will just overheat (which changes for the better, in my opinion, in the second game). You can't dodge and it's generally unwise to charge at the enemy on the higher difficulties, regardless of your character class, so you really just end up feeling like a massive brick wall with a gun. If you're going to attempt insanity, it's almost not worth it to play anything but the soldier class because it synergizes best with the game mechanics and can naturally regenerate health. However, I think the issues with the combat mechanics are more than compensated for by the quality of the story.  2) On a related note, the insanity difficulty is hard, but for bad reasons. It basically just amps up the health that enemies have by a lot and their damage by a little, making most battles drawn-out wars of attrition. If you're new, which I can't imagine is likely at this point, or coming from ME 2/3, I'd suggest you just play it on easy. Nobody's going to judge you. The point of the game is its storyline, in any case, and easy/normal are best for experiencing it without becoming frustated by large numbers of drawn-out battles.  3) After ME1, the combat mechanics improve exponentially, but the quality of the storyline declines. Compared to ME1, ME2 and 3 feel somewhat cheap. They're still worth it, and their stories are not by any means bad, but they are outshone by ME1 by quite a lot. The ending of the third game, particularly--even after the free DLC that EA put out to try to fix its problems--*will* leave you feeling cheated. The Citadel DLC will soften the blow considerably, though, so you should definitely get it, at the least. Aside from the beginning and ending of ME3, the storyline is solid and the major secondary plot points opened in ME1 and 2 are actually resolved very well.

A must play decadent pure space epic science-fiction adventure   Cons  * Storyline leans towards the predictable side but it did have more than enough twists. A lot of cliche references were borrewed from other science fiction elements in games/books/movies. * My expectations were a lot higher than what was experienced, but still enjoyed it immenesly. Perhaps I was a little unfair in my unrealistic expectations of the game. * At times the gameplay/mechanics and storyline can appear a little shallow. * At times the gamplay/mechanics can seem overly tedious or repetiive with no apparent reason to be. * Cannot jump! Grr - that annoyed me. Especially with all the running around I seemed to do everywhere it would ease the pain even a little.   Pros  * Awesome back story and world lore. * Great visuals/audio and environment. * Great storyline and progression. * Excellent soundtrack that did not annoy even throughout the entire play through * Added to my very short candidates list of games that 'I will play again' even after completion.   Conclusion  Storyline was slightly predictable but original in execution and the originality of core storyline elements were distinguished enough to surpass the predictability. Overall, this was a fantastic game and I enjoyed it thoroughly, however I did feel at times some of the gameplay seemed overly tedious and repetitive (eg: navigating through the ship) and a little shallow.  BUT I can't say enough good things about it and in fact struggling to fault it at all. If you like sci-fi genre as much as I do, this is a definite 'must play' - there is no question about it.

Great graphics, great gameplay, but the story...  The story is simply amazing.  While the basic plot is a simple military sci-fi, it is the smooth integration of player choice, characters, and gameplay that make Mass Effect special. The plot follows Commander Shepard, a human commando, and his journey through the galaxy as he tries to catch a rogue agent bent on the destruction of humanity and the aliens that live within the Milky Way. The defining attribute of Mass Effect is the seamless player choice that is present throughout the story. The player is given moral choices that affect the characters and situations that occur in the game. Between being the Paragon of virtuous moral code and the renegade commander hell bent on completing the job no matter what the cost, every situation can be approached with the player's own choice.   This ties in very well with the character development, something that not many other studios other than Bioware are proficient at. The crew of the Normady becomes populated with not just human soldiers and crewmen, but also engineers and scientists from alien races. The relationships and interactions with each character are unique and provide deep character development. This is the highlight of the experience, and the space opera setting only makes this a more immersive and spectacular experience. By far, Mass Effect is the best game in the Mass Effect Trilogy, every time I start a new save, the opening cutscene always manages to evoke the same excitement that creates a truly epic introduction to the game. Unmarred by the mistakes made with ME3, and providing a deeper and larger story and plot than ME2, Mass Effect, providing the mystery and excitement of discovering the story and setting, good character development, a satisfying conclusion, and a plethora of unique environments, is well worth my thumbs up.  10/10 did play again, many times.

The start to one of my favorite franchises. This game has a huge amount to offer in terms of things to do - places to visit, characters to interact with, secrets to find. I absolutely love the lore and setting of this game, and I think the way the story is told is brilliant. The fact that you have your own spaceship and you get to make a lot of decisions as to how the story progresses - both in the core story and in terms of your relations with your crew - is something I appreciate immensely. It's easy to get immersed into this game and spend a ton of time, in no small part thanks to the variery of things you can do.  It definitely has the worst combat system in the franchise - shooting and moving about just feels awkward and clunky at times. However, the fact that you have two squad memebers with different, cool abilities helps spice it up a lot, and adds a whole new element to the combat and stops it from getting stale.  As opposed to later entries, this game has a pretty solid RPG progression system. Personally I'm not a massive fan of the relatively expansive stats system, but it's fine. I have a bigger gripe with the equipment system, mainly just because the menu is a pain in the ♥♥♥.  Either way, if you're looking for a huge action-RPG with 30+ hours worth of a very interesting story and universe, you can't go wrong with this.

Mass Effect; You cannot be a BioWare fan or a gamer for that matter now without hearing something about this glorious mixture of RPG and 3rd-Person Shooter. A very emmersive and beautiful sci-fi fantasy that, in true BioWare sense, will leave you craving for more. Take control of your own Commander Shepard as Humanity takes its place in the ruling/dominant races of the universe. Travel across the galaxy, visiting man star sysytems, going through many beautiful battles and playing through a truely wonderous and interactive story that changes based on your actions in the game. The universe is threatened by an ancient alien race bent on cleansing the many systems of all intelligant life, and Shepard and the crew of the Normandy (Earths new prototype star ship built with alien technology) are the only ones that know the truth of it. It is up to them to bring the truth to light and save the universe from imminant destruction. I give this magnificent game a 9.5/10.

The leveling and inventory systems more than make up for this aspect, however. Comparatively the other games only give you a handful of weapon and armour choices and drastically cut down on ability leveling to focus more on making the game combat friendly; which was a step up from this game, but overall hurt the series by taking it away from its roots.

I love the setting, I love the story, I love the characters, I love the attention to detail... I HATE the combat system. Enemies take inordinate amounts of damage to put down while your own allies go down at the drop of a hat, no matter how much you micromanage your inventory and weapons you can never seem to get an edge, you can never tell where grenades are going, and every encounter is scaled to your level so the whole thing is pointless anyway. And this is on NORMAL!  It's not bad enough to ruin the game - far from it, it is still an impressive title - but the combat system really lets it down.

Mass Effect is a great RPG that takes place in the Milky Way Galaxy. Every decision you make in the game will have repercussions (even in Mass Effect 2 and 3). You’re playing as Commander Shepard (You can set your character as a male or female). Shepard’s is mission is to help the citizens of The Milky Way Galaxy and find clues to various situations, help them out and see where It might lead.  Mass Effect has a huge diverse “universe” of aliens and other sentient beings coexisting with humans. Of cause there are political issues that causes tremendous heat between the races, but something has come up that unites them all. And it’s Shepard’s job to find out what it is with his squad.  This is my first RPG game I’ve ever played and I enjoyed every bit of it. I really like the idea of being able to select your dialogues and that it has an effect on your character. The more you play “Shepard” you will either end up as a passive, aggressive, neutral person – there’s no right or wrong decision. It’s YOUR decision!  I recommend Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2 and the 3rd game. This is a great  enhancement for your game library.  Peace.

Still one of my all-time favourite RPGs, not to mention one of Bioware's best games.  A vast improvement over the console version (which I've had since day 1 and have clocked up hundreds of hours of play across 20+ playthroughs), the shooting mechanics are unchanged but combat feels MUCH smoother and the hacking minigame is so much better than the 'tap A/B/X/Y' system. As is common with pre-ME2 Bioware, they have managed to craft an excellent story with really great characters, meaningful decisions, and a superb sci-fi atmosphere and world. This is topped off with some well-done level design (which can get repetitive, but it's not a major detracting factor to me), some of the most gorgeous artistic visuals (just wait until you get to Ilos!), and a memorable music score which further lends to the very distinctive atmosphere this game has.  I don't think that the sequels managed to match this game in the things that it got right, after this Bioware seemed to focus a lot more on making the series into a TPS rather than an RPG - which is fine for some, but I wasn't all that keen on how the game strayed so far from its roots. The inventory can be a bit cluttered with a rather meh UI system, but was it really necessary to cut the thing out of the other games rather than work on improving it?  I am also in the minority of people who loves the Mako and planetary exploration. While the indoor structures do get quite repetitive, as I said, this is the only game in the trilogy which made me feel like you're part of the galaxy with the freedom to explore anywhere.  If you've missed out on Mass Effect for some reason, now is the perfect time to get it.

The combination of shooting and bio-tech weaponry was pretty good as well, but don't expect a 'real' shooter like modern warfare and it's ilk.  Where the game really shines though is the really good background story. It has also plenty of side missions to keep you busy and if you're not in a real hurry you can hit the triple digits in invested hours on this one.

This is part 1 of the best gaming trilogy ever made. It was the first RPG-like game I played, and though I didn't think I would like it all that much it hooked me immediately. It is by no means a technically perfect game - the second and third games have this one beat graphically and in some gameplay elements as well (in particular, the inventory system in this first game is a huge pain). However, it is generally considered to have the best and deepest story and lore, and has the best character exposition and interaction of the series.  The main problem with the series as a whole is that you can't get Mass Effect 3 on Steam, and instead have to go through Origin (bleh). Also, the ending of the third game, and therefore the trilogy, kinda sucks without the DLC, some of which is free and some you have to pay for. But the bad taste of the ending is totally worth it for the rest of the package.  So in short, if you enjoy story-driven games or space settings for games, try this series out. Even if you aren't a big RPG fan in general, this one may surprise you. It certainly far exceeded my expectations, to the point that the entire Mass Effect series, when taken as a single saga, is probably my favorite game of all time.

The beginning of the Mass Effect trilogy! What else can i say? Probably everything has already been said so there is little i can add since this game is a few years old now, but i'll try my best to describe this game.  Mass Effect is a cinematic Third Persion Shooter RPG with high emphasis on conversations between your character and other characters you will encounter in the game. Throughout the game you will gain new skills for your character and companions and make them at combat or utility (Using Hacking/Electronics and conversations).  You are also able to (Compared to the two later entries in the series) collect actual loot (Armor, weapons and mods) which also allow you to improve your overall combat efficency.  But, combat in the first game of the trilogy is not really the best around is clunky at best. Also the exploration elements (Driving the APC/Tank) can get somewhat boring quickly since it takes up a whole lot of time (That is if you want exp and loot). And some of the side mission enviroments are REALLY repetive at most.  What about the story? You are commander Shepard, who you can shape to your liking (You are also able to choose what gender Shepard has, which can change some conversations in the game) with both looks and background story (3 Premilitary backgrounds and 3 military backgrounds) and class in the game (Which decides what powers and combat abilities you will have). This allows your main character to be pretty much whatever you want and affect his/her backstory in the game.  You end up in a story similar to Freespace 2 (In case you have played it): Its the future and humanity is now living amongst the stars, and a rouge agent is trying to bring back and ancient evil to kill all known life in the galaxy! Now it's up to Shepard&CO to stop this guy at all costs!  Yeah, i dont want to write too much about the story, it's up to you to experience! But to me, this game has a damn good story i really don't want to spoil, and the side characters/companions you meet flesh out the story even more.  And a note; You can load your character into Mass Effect 2 when you complete Mass Effect (1) which allows you to continue you story where you left off, and the second game in the series gets even better...   But lets not talk about the third game yet, ok?

It's clear that BioWare put way more effort into the main story than the side quests, but I still played as many of them as I could find. The 'Choose Your Own Adventure' aspect of this game is interesting, and I wonder what a subsequent playthrough with different choices would result in. Even if it didn't make a huge difference, some of the choices in the game made me really think about what the potential consequences were, which is something I hadn't experienced before in a video game. Note: It actually took me about 10 hours to beat this game (I played through about half of it while offline).   Mass Effect is a great action RPG that offers a lot of customization. You can play as a male or female. You can be good-natured or somewhat-ruthless. Most importantly, key decisions that you make in this game carry over to Mass Effect 2 and Mass Effect 3 as well.   Regardless of gender, you play as human Commander Shepard. The game starts with you trying to save a human colony from an alien attack. This missions servers to get you accustomed to the mechanics of the game. Combat plays like a third person shooter with abilities, such as being able to deal more damage for a short period of time.   Mass Effect has some really strong RPG elements. You have abilities that you can use to give you an edge in combat and you get a good amount of character customization. The dialogue options are really interesting because most of the key events in the game are dependent on Shephard's morality. Some situations require you to say something threatening to defuse the situation whereas others need you to be kind-hearted. That's the great thing about Mass Effect though: there really is no wrong choice. You get to play the game how you want to play it.   I have a few complaints about Mass Effect. The combat is pretty bad. For some reason, sniper rifles have an annoying sway to them. I get that it's an RPG, but that doens't mean that the action should suffer. Additionally, the inventory system is pretty terrible. Most guns that you pick up are absolute trash. Especially near the end of the game, you'll find yourself having to clear out your inventory. The abilities during combat also have frustratingly-long cooldown, so you're better off just shooting.   Overall, Mass Effect has a great sci-fi story and is definitely worth playing.

Easily among, if not, my favorite RPG(s) of all time, Mass Effect is an extremely unique game. In my opinion, it is already a classic that I would place among other masterpieces such as the early Fallout games or Planescape: Torment.  Story: Probably Mass Effect's greatest aspect is its story. The game's universe is extremely interesting and immersive. Everything seems scientifically plausible and is put together in a very desirable package. It is often stated Mass Effect is a Space Opera, and I believe that label is more than perfect for this game. Beyond the backstory and universe, Mass Effect's characters are very well-written and interesting, even the mundane humans have interesting stories, such as the pilot of your ship who has a bone-weakening disease. The plot itself is also captivating, bringing in influences from Lovecraftian horror to the science fiction shows and movies of the late 20th century.  Gameplay: Mass Effect's gameplay is overall pretty decent. It does feel clanky and aged at times, but it by no means makes the game unplayable. There are certain levels of the game I loathe to encounter whenever I replay it (Feros...), but sticking through those rough times and comparing it to the much more fun levels ultimately means I can't say the gameplay is bad by any means. A feature frequently criticized are the (mostly) optional levels where you drive around in an APC called the Mako. I personally enjoyed them but that could likely be just my driving desire to explore the various worlds of the Mass Effect universe.  Replayability: I would recommend most people play Mass Effect at least twice. There are many reasons to come back to Mass Effect such as being able to play as a either a male or a female, romancing different people, or making situational choices. The dialogue your character can say can range from being a kind and noble person to a borderline sociopath. For example: You can use charisma to charm the audience of a reporter trying to make you look bad, or alternatively you can tell her you've 'had enough of her snide insinuations' and punch her in the face. In addition to this there are multiple classes you can play as, from a decidated soldier to a technology specialist  Ultimately, even if you think Mass Effect has fallen from grace (I did not like Mass Effect 3 in the slightest), Mass Effect 1 really has standed the test of time has an incredible RPG and one of Bioware's finest creations.

This game..... This game..... i've played over 200 hrs. of this game, even more of Mass Effect 2 and Mass Effect 3. It would take more words than are in my vocabulary to describe how fantastic this game is. Almost (for no game is perfect) every aspect of this game is perfect. The only real issues that i have with this game are combat, saveing, and leveling. The combat is very clunky, the cover system is archaec though in some aspects much more realistic than its follow up titles. Instead of locking into cover you run into any form of cover that can be used which leads to unintentional cover breaks and on higher difficulties can lead to your death. The saving system is absoulty terribe. There are little to no autosaves, meaning you have to manually save each time really, this has caused me a few rage quits. (so save often!). lastly the leveling system though complex really has no effect. All the tiers of the skill cause minor improvements which are hardly noticable. Now for the good, (will try to be brief) The real reason this game is worth my full attention, even as an EA title, is its story and characters. Mass Effect is a wondeful story, if a little overdone, all the way from the start to finish you'll be waiting to see what Shepard has to deal with next. The Characters of this story belong in the higher ranks of great characters. Every single character will leave an impact somehow in your memory, either as being your friend or just someone there who occassionally says something, but their strength comes in when you talk to them, each has a thought out personality. Each has their own flaws (which i will not rob you of the satisfaction of figureing it out) and strengths that comes up in dialoge. The best part of the Mass Effect series lies in its base coding. Normal RPG's of this caliber make an event permantly happen, it won't matter what you choose it will not matter. In Mass Effect however it does. you can import your save files into ME2 and then into ME3 to see how your actions impact the galaxy for the years to come.  All in All i give Mass Effect a 99\100 a near flawless game that is worth every ounce of your time
